III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Former Youth J told Complainant he was suicidal when the facility
discharged him to his parents on 1/20/24. Hours later he was
accepted for psychiatric hospitalization.
Investigation Safehaus Too does not contract with MDHHS and there is no
worker assigned to Former Youth J’s case. His legal guardians
are his parents. Safehaus Too does not have the authority to sign
youths into the hospital and they do not transport youths for
external psychiatric evaluations. With the guardian’s permission
Safehaus Too can complete an internal psychiatric evaluation
onsite if needed.
Interviews:
On 1/22/24 I notified Complainant/Hospital Social Worker that I
was assigned this investigation. She had no additional licensing
concerns pertaining to Safehaus Too.
I contacted Director and requested Former Youth J’s discharge
paperwork. I communicated with Chief Administrator via email
and phone.
On 1/24/24 I interviewed Former Youth J, age 17, at Havenwyck
Hospital. He said he was at Safehaus for eight days and was
discharged to his parents on 1/20/24. On 1/19/24, he said he
informed a Safehaus Nurse he felt urges to harm himself and
Nurse was going to talk about it with staff. The next day on
1/20/24 Former Youth J said he was not ready to go home with his
mother and told her this when she came to pick him up. “She
(mother) said she was ‘done with my ass and had shit to do.’ She
left me there and it hurt. Staff 1 dialed CPS and I talked to them.
I told them I would kill myself if I went home with her (mother).
Clinical Director (via phone) told Supervisor I was to go to
inpatient at Havenwyck Hospital. Supervisor gave me two
choices. I could take an ambulance to ER for a psychiatric
evaluation or Supervisor would get my parents to come back to
Safehaus Too and pick me up.” Former Youth J said his parents
2

returned to the facility to get him, but rather than take him directly
to Havenwyck, they drove him home instead. “I stayed alone in
the car in my driveway for 40 minutes.” Then his parents drove
him for a psychiatric evaluation. Former Youth J was accepted for
inpatient hospitalization and admitted to Havenwyck Hospital that
same day.
I interviewed Clinical Director on 1/24/24. She has worked at
Safehaus Too for four years. On Saturday 1/20/24, Clinical
Director was not at the facility, but was receiving phone calls from
both Youth J’s mother and Supervisor simultaneously. At the time
of his initial discharge, she said Youth J became escalated after
his mother came and left without him. Over the phone, Clinical
Director said she heard Youth J threaten that if discharged to his
mother, he would run away. “He was yelling asking to be put in
the foster care system. We explained we couldn’t do that. Then
he refused to be discharged and insisted he was staying. I
convinced his mother to return and verbally told her if Youth J was
making suicidal threats, she should take him to the local
emergency room.”
Clinical Director reported the following:
A Depression Scale completed by Therapist with Youth J on
1/11/24 at admission indicated a score of 13. A follow up
Depression Scale completed on 1/19/24 indicated a score of 6,
which is considered mild depression.
Nurse assessed Youth J on 1/18/24 and documented “thoughts of
self-harm - absent.” Nurse assessed Youth J on 1/19/24 and
documented “thoughts of self-harm – occasional.”
On checklists completed by Therapist on 1/18/24 and 1/19/24,
suicidal ideation was not identified. A Clinical Therapy note by
Therapist on 1/19/24 indicated Youth J “presents with an
appropriate affect and denies SI. He is at his baseline and his
crisis has stabilized. He is preparing for discharge from program
and follow up with outpatient services.”
Documents reviewed:
Nurse assessments, Depression Scales and therapy notes
provided were consistent with Clinical Director’s verbal report.
Safehaus Too Discharge Release Form dated 1/20/24 at 4:26pm
signed by Therapist on 1/19/24 indicated Youth J was admitted on
1/11/24 due to suicidal ideation and depression. Significant
findings indicated “Alleviated suicidal ideation and impulses.
3

Returned to highest previous level of daily functioning…”
Discharge condition indicated “Patient is at baseline and stable to
continue with outpatient therapy. Discharge Home to legal
guardian with outpatient appointment at Easterseals on 1/25/24 at
1pm.”
Analysis Documentation dated 1/19/24 indicated Former Youth J was not
suicidal. However, when his mother arrived to pick him up from
Safehaus Too on 1/20/24, he did not want to go with her. Youth
J’s mother became irritated and left him at the facility. The facility
contacted centralized intake and Former Youth J said he told the
screener he would kill himself if he went home with his mother. At
the same time, Clinical Director remotely via phone convinced the
mother to return to Safehaus Too to pick up her child. His mother
returned and Youth J left with her after Clinical Director verbally
advised her to take him to the ER if he was making suicidal
threats. According to the youth, his mother drove him home
where he stayed alone in the car for 40 minutes until she came
out and drove him to the hospital where Complainant assessed
him for psychiatric hospitalization. He was accepted for inpatient
treatment and transported to Havenwyck Hospital.
Former Youth J was released to his mother (legal guardian) on
1/20/24 and then taken to the hospital.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A youth at Safehaus Too expressed suicidal thoughts to a nurse prior to discharge, but clinical documentation from the day before indicated he was at baseline with denied suicidal ideation. Upon discharge to his mother, the youth refused to go, the mother left, and the youth threatened suicide to a CPS screener; the facility's Clinical Director, via phone, convinced the mother to return and verbally advised her to take him to the ER if he made suicidal threats, which she eventually did after a delay, leading to his psychiatric hospitalization. While the report concludes no licensing violation was established, the facility's discharge process and communication with the guardian failed to ensure immediate safety for a youth expressing acute risk.
